content.webTitle: Manuel Pellegrini says win at Dynamo Kyiv justifies weak team at Chelsea

fields.headline: Manuel Pellegrini says win at Dynamo Kyiv justifies weak team at Chelsea
fields.bodyText: Manuel Pellegrini said Manchester City’s 3-1 victory against Dynamo Kyiv in the Champions League last-16 opening leg on Wednesday night vindicated his controversial decision to rest key players for the FA Cup defeat by Chelsea. Pellegrini started six teenagers at Stamford Bridge as City were thrashed 5-1 in the fifth round on Sunday, leading to the manager receiving criticism from some quarters and being accused of disrespecting the competition. But, having selected the strongest XI available to him for the match in Ukraine and then watched them comfortably beat the hosts, Pellegrini felt emboldened enough to stand by his weekend selection. “I think it’s important to take the right decision and think about a lot of things, about why you take this decision,” he said. “But in this case, having just 13 players, it was a key decision to rest the team that day. Unfortunately we could not continue in the FA Cup.” Goals from Sergio Agüero and David Silva in the 15th and 40th minutes respectively were answered only by Vitaliy Buyalskyi in the 58th minute before Yaya Touré’s strike a minute before the end gave City a firm advantage for the return leg at the Etihad Stadium in three weeks’ time and puts them in pole position to qualify for the Champions League quarter-finals for the first time. Pellegrini said: “I’m very happy because it is a very good result. It is not finished but playing away and having a two-goal lead is very good. The team played well and had lots of chances. Maybe when it was 2-1 we had moments of doubt, but then we got the third goal. Is the tie settled? No, it is important in football to never think it is finished. But to have that third goal gives us more confidence for the second leg.” After being knocked out by Barcelona at this stage in each of the past two years, Pellegrini is pleased with City’s advance as a side in Europe. “Each season we improve a little bit more,” he said. “The last two seasons we qualified for the last 16 and this season we made the important progress of winning the group, which was an improvement from last season. We now have the chance to arrive at the next stage and it’s important if you can be among the best eight teams in Europe.” Vincent Kompany, the captain, was also happy with City’s result and display. “The performance was good, with a lot of high pressing,” said the defender before praising an eye-catching late save by Joe Hart. “Three-one is a good result and we are happy with it. Joe Hart is an unbelievable keeper. When he was called upon he did it well. We are going into the second leg with a fairly good chance to go through, which has not been the case before. We looked like a team that was hungry for success tonight. “I feel like I am contradicting myself a little after the FA Cup but I feel like every cup is a priority. Every game is a priority. It is not easy to predict which competition you will do well in.”
